elements.content: ACM-1 is the first example of an organoarsine metal–organic framework (MOF), prepared using a new pyridyl-functionalized triarylarsine ligand coordinated to Ni­(II) nodes. ACM-1 has micropores that are decorated with cis-diarsine coordination pockets. Postsynthetic metalation of ACM-1 with AuCl under facile conditions studied by single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals the installation of dimeric Au2Cl2 complexes via the formation of As–Au bonds. The Au­(I) dimers display exceptionally short aurophilic bonds (2.76 Å) induced by the rigidity of the MOF, which acts as a unique solid-state ligand.
elements.clean_text: ACM-1 is the first example of an organoarsine metal-organic framework (MOF), prepared using a new pyridyl-functionalized triarylarsine ligand coordinated to Ni(II) nodes. ACM-1 has micropores that are decorated with cis-diarsine coordination pockets. Postsynthetic metalation of ACM-1 with AuCl under facile conditions studied by single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals the installation of dimeric Au2Cl2 complexes via the formation of As-Au bonds. The Au(I) dimers display exceptionally short aurophilic bonds (2.76 Å) induced by the rigidity of the MOF, which acts as a unique solid-state ligand.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) hold unique potential as structurally well-defined “solid-state ligands” (SSLs) to support the confinement of unusual low-valent coordination complexes within their micropores. Heterogenized single-site complexes can affect various small molecule transformations, enhance gas sorption via strong adsorbate interactions at the open metal sites, and may be operated in liquid- and gas-phase environments that molecular analogues cannot tolerate.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) hold unique potential as structurally well-defined "solid-state ligands" (SSLs) to support the confinement of unusual low-valent coordination complexes within their micropores. Heterogenized single-site complexes can affect various small molecule transformations, enhance gas sorption via strong adsorbate interactions at the open metal sites, and may be operated in liquid- and gas-phase environments that molecular analogues cannot tolerate.

elements.content: MOFs that permit postsynthetic coordination of low-valent transition metal complexes are comparatively rare, especially examples that can form stable chelates. Chelating ligands are of great importance in organometallic chemistry and catalysis, but preparing SSL-MOFs with similar moieties presents a synthetic challenge. Such MOFs can be prepared directly using Lewis base ligands that are ubiquitous in molecular catalysts (e.g., phosphines, amines). However, it is difficult to control MOF assembly on a level that permits the formation of structurally precise chelate sites. This problem can be overcome by postsynthetic installation of chelating moieties via organic coupling reactions, as demonstrated by Cohen, Yaghi, Lin and others. Alternatively, preformed molecular chelate complexes can be used to prepare MOFs, as demonstrated recently by our group and Wade et al. to obtain bis(phosphine)- and PCP-pincer-based MOFs.
elements.clean_text: MOFs that permit postsynthetic coordination of low-valent transition metal complexes are comparatively rare, especially examples that can form stable chelates. Chelating ligands are of great importance in organometallic chemistry and catalysis, but preparing SSL-MOFs with similar moieties presents a synthetic challenge. Such MOFs can be prepared directly using Lewis base ligands that are ubiquitous in molecular catalysts (e.g., phosphines, amines). However, it is difficult to control MOF assembly on a level that permits the formation of structurally precise chelate sites. This problem can be overcome by postsynthetic installation of chelating moieties via organic coupling reactions, as demonstrated by Cohen, Yaghi, Lin and others. Alternatively, preformed molecular chelate complexes can be used to prepare MOFs, as demonstrated recently by our group and Wade et al. to obtain bis(phosphine)- and PCP-pincer-based MOFs.

elements.content: SSL-MOFs present a unique and exciting opportunity to generate coordination complexes in “nonequilibrium” states, by exploiting the inherent rigidity of a MOF to fix donor atoms in specific positions, thus imposing geometric strain on coordinated metal centers. The imposition of nonequilibrium metal–ligand bond distances or angles is well-studied in molecular catalysis as a means to tune the electron density at a metal site, e.g., through ligand steric bulk effects.
elements.clean_text: SSL-MOFs present a unique and exciting opportunity to generate coordination complexes in "nonequilibrium" states, by exploiting the inherent rigidity of a MOF to fix donor atoms in specific positions, thus imposing geometric strain on coordinated metal centers. The imposition of nonequilibrium metal-ligand bond distances or angles is well-studied in molecular catalysis as a means to tune the electron density at a metal site, e.g., through ligand steric bulk effects.

elements.content: As an example of this hypothesis, we recently reported a triphenylphosphine-based SSL-MOF called PCM-101, which is decorated with Lewis basic phosphine-P sites arranged in trans-orientations inside the pores. Postsynthetic installation of Cu2Br2 dimers tracked by single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed the imposition of compressive strain, resulting in unusually short Cu···Cu distances because the P···P separation in PCM-101 was ∼5% shorter than the average distance observed in molecular analogues.
elements.clean_text: As an example of this hypothesis, we recently reported a triphenylphosphine-based SSL-MOF called PCM-101, which is decorated with Lewis basic phosphine-P sites arranged in trans-orientations inside the pores. Postsynthetic installation of Cu2Br2 dimers tracked by single-crystal X-ray diffraction revealed the imposition of compressive strain, resulting in unusually short Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distances because the P⋅⋅⋅P separation in PCM-101 was ~5% shorter than the average distance observed in molecular analogues.

elements.content: On the basis of this compelling initial result, we began to search for routes to prepare other MOFs with similar coordination pockets. Simultaneously, we decided to investigate the preparation of MOFs based on triarylarsines (AsAr3), referred to as arsine coordination materials (ACMs). To the best of our knowledge, there are no prior reports of triarylarsine-based MOFs, even though arsines are commonplace in organometallic chemistry. Organoarsines are structurally and chemically similar to organophosphines but are less basic because the As-4sp 3 lone pair is more diffuse. For this reason, arylarsines are commonly used as phosphine surrogates to modulate catalytic reactivity. However, leaching is a major consideration industrially, due to the toxicity of As­(III) and As­(V) species. We propose that the construction of As-based MOFs can directly mitigate As toxicity issues because MOFs have zero volatility and are more stable than molecular ligands. ACM-SSLs could provide unique catalytic platforms, and may also find utility in the sequestration of toxic heavy metals (e.g., Cd­(II)) from aqueous media.
elements.clean_text: On the basis of this compelling initial result, we began to search for routes to prepare other MOFs with similar coordination pockets. Simultaneously, we decided to investigate the preparation of MOFs based on triarylarsines (AsAr3), referred to as arsine coordination materials (ACMs). To the best of our knowledge, there are no prior reports of triarylarsine-based MOFs, even though arsines are commonplace in organometallic chemistry. Organoarsines are structurally and chemically similar to organophosphines but are less basic because the As-4sp 3 lone pair is more diffuse. For this reason, arylarsines are commonly used as phosphine surrogates to modulate catalytic reactivity. However, leaching is a major consideration industrially, due to the toxicity of As(III) and As(V) species. We propose that the construction of As-based MOFs can directly mitigate As toxicity issues because MOFs have zero volatility and are more stable than molecular ligands. ACM-SSLs could provide unique catalytic platforms, and may also find utility in the sequestration of toxic heavy metals (e.g., Cd(II)) from aqueous media.

elements.content: With this in mind, we synthesized the AsAr3 ligand, tris(4-(pyridin-4-yl)­phenyl)­arsine (TPPA; ). TPPA was prepared in gram quantities by lithium-halogen exchange and Suzuki coupling ((i),(ii)). As a MOF building block, TPPA is a 3-D, 3-connected trigonal pyramidal linker with extended phenylpyridine arms and ancillary pyridyl-N donors. The substantially different coordination affinities of “hard” N and “soft” As donors in TPPA facilitates the direct formation of MOFs with vacant As: sites using 3d-transition metals, via selective binding to N atoms.
elements.clean_text: With this in mind, we synthesized the AsAr3 ligand, tris(4-(pyridin-4-yl)phenyl)arsine (TPPA; ). TPPA was prepared in gram quantities by lithium-halogen exchange and Suzuki coupling ((i),(ii)). As a MOF building block, TPPA is a 3-D, 3-connected trigonal pyramidal linker with extended phenylpyridine arms and ancillary pyridyl-N donors. The substantially different coordination affinities of "hard" N and "soft" As donors in TPPA facilitates the direct formation of MOFs with vacant As: sites using 3d-transition metals, via selective binding to N atoms.

elements.content:
Synthesis Scheme for ACM-1<xref ref-type="fn" rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

(i) AsCl3, THF, −78 °C → +25 °C; (ii) Pd­(PPh3)4 (5 mol %), 4:1:1 toluene:ethanol:H2O, 105 °C, 96 h; (iii) Ni­(BF4)2, 5:2:1 DMF:methanol:H2O, 75 °C, 48–96 h.
elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis Scheme for ACM-1      a (i) AsCl3, THF, -78 °C → +25 °C; (ii) Pd(PPh3)4 (5 mol %), 4:1:1 toluene:ethanol:H2O, 105 °C, 96 h; (iii) Ni(BF4)2, 5:2:1 DMF:methanol:H2O, 75 °C, 48-96 h.

elements.content:
(i) AsCl3, THF, −78 °C → +25 °C; (ii) Pd­(PPh3)4 (5 mol %), 4:1:1 toluene:ethanol:H2O, 105 °C, 96 h; (iii) Ni­(BF4)2, 5:2:1 DMF:methanol:H2O, 75 °C, 48–96 h.

As a first demonstration of this principle, reaction of TPPA and a secondary pillaring ligand (1,1′-biphenyl-4,4′-dicarboxylic acid; BPDH2) with Ni­(BF4)2 at 75 °C in an organic solvent mixture under N2 results in the formation of a single crystalline phase, named ACM-1 ((iii)). ACM-1 is cationic, having formula unit [Ni2(μ2-OH)­(TPPA)­(BPD)]­[BF4], determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction and confirmed by C,H,N,F elemental analysis and FT-IR (Figure S1). The structure of ACM-1 was solved in the orthorhombic space group Pnna (Z = 4). Each TPPA is coordinated to three symmetry-equivalent Ni­(II) ions through its p-pyridyl-N donors (A); the phenylpyridine arms are twisted into a propeller configuration commonly observed in molecular systems. The inorganic nodes are composed of [Ni2(μ2-OH)]3+ dimers that are syn,syn-bridged by equivalent carboxylate groups of the dianionic BPD pillaring ligand and a μ2-OH (B). The octahedral coordination environment of Ni1 is completed by fac-oriented N-donors; each [Ni2(μ2-OH)]3+ unit is an 8-connected node with bicapped trigonal prismatic geometry. The C–As–C bond angles range between 98.6° and 101.0°, confirming that each As has an available lone pair (C).

a (i) AsCl3, THF, -78 °C → +25 °C; (ii) Pd(PPh3)4 (5 mol %), 4:1:1 toluene:ethanol:H2O, 105 °C, 96 h; (iii) Ni(BF4)2, 5:2:1 DMF:methanol:H2O, 75 °C, 48-96 h.  

As a first demonstration of this principle, reaction of TPPA and a secondary pillaring ligand (1,1'-biphenyl-4,4'-dicarboxylic acid; BPDH2) with Ni(BF4)2 at 75 °C in an organic solvent mixture under N2 results in the formation of a single crystalline phase, named ACM-1 ((iii)). ACM-1 is cationic, having formula unit [Ni2(μ2-OH)(TPPA)(BPD)][BF4], determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction and confirmed by C,H,N,F elemental analysis and FT-IR (Figure S1). The structure of ACM-1 was solved in the orthorhombic space group Pnna (Z = 4). Each TPPA is coordinated to three symmetry-equivalent Ni(II) ions through its p-pyridyl-N donors (A); the phenylpyridine arms are twisted into a propeller configuration commonly observed in molecular systems. The inorganic nodes are composed of [Ni2(μ2-OH)]3+ dimers that are syn,syn-bridged by equivalent carboxylate groups of the dianionic BPD pillaring ligand and a μ2-OH (B). The octahedral coordination environment of Ni1 is completed by fac-oriented N-donors; each [Ni2(μ2-OH)]3+ unit is an 8-connected node with bicapped trigonal prismatic geometry. The C-As-C bond angles range between 98.6° and 101.0°, confirming that each As has an available lone pair (C).

elements.content: (A) Extended asymmetric unit of ACM-1 showing the basic network connectivity; BPD ligands are drawn in cyan. (B) Alternative view of an 8-connected [Ni2(μ2-OH)]3+ node. (C) Distorted pyramidal environment of the As­(III) donor site, and bond angles (deg).
elements.clean_text: 1  (A) Extended asymmetric unit of ACM-1 showing the basic network connectivity; BPD ligands are drawn in cyan. (B) Alternative view of an 8-connected [Ni2(μ2-OH)]3+ node. (C) Distorted pyramidal environment of the As(III) donor site, and bond angles (deg).

elements.content: ACM-1 has a 3-D micropore structure with three types of pore windows ( and S4). The 3-fold symmetry of the TPPA ligands engenders triangular openings with a maximum accessible edge length of 13.4 Å lying parallel to the crystallographic a-axis (A). The largest, rhombus-shaped openings have accessible corner-to-corner dimensions of 14.4 × 15.7 Å (B). Smaller hexagonal pores of accessible diameter = 14. 3 Å lie parallel the c-axis (C). ACM-1 shows permanent porosity upon activation at 75 °C in vacuo. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) shows that loss of solvent from the pores occurs between 25 and 125 °C (∼31% of the total starting mass), after which there is no further mass loss until the onset of degradation ca. 325 °C (Figure S2). The calculated BET surface areas using CO2 and N2 are 1154 and 1021 m2 g–1, respectively. The CO2 pore volume of 0.60 cm3 g–1 is in close agreement with the value obtained using the VOID utility in Platon (0.63 cm3 g–1; corresponding to a 53% accessible void space). ACM-1 shows highly reversible Type-I sorption of a number of small molecule probe gases without hysteresis (A and S3). The measured adsorption capacities for various gases were: N2, 545 cm3 mmol–1 (77 K, 0.95 atm); CO2, 486 cm3 mmol–1 (196 K, 0.95 atm); O2, 575 cm3 mmol–1 (77 K, 0.20 atm); and H2, 218 cm3 mmol–1 (77 K, 0.95 atm).

The measured adsorption capacities for various gases were: N2, 545 cm3 mmol-1 (77 K, 0.95 atm); CO2, 486 cm3 mmol-1 (196 K, 0.95 atm); O2, 575 cm3 mmol-1 (77 K, 0.20 atm); and H2, 218 cm3 mmol-1 (77 K, 0.95 atm).

elements.content: (A) Comparison of adsorption isotherms for ACM-1 (solid markers) versus Au–ACM-1 (open markers): red = O2, 77 K; blue = N2, 77 K; green = CO2, 196 K; black = H2, 77 K. (B) Comparison of the simulated and observed PXRD patterns for ACM-1 (black = model; blue = observed) and Au–ACM-1 (red = model; green = observed).

(B) Comparison of the simulated and observed PXRD patterns for ACM-1 (black = model; blue = observed) and Au-ACM-1 (red = model; green = observed).

elements.content: Closer examination of the extended structure of ACM-1 along the c-axis reveals pairs of As atoms arranged in a cis-orientation (C and A; purple atoms). This arrangement is derived from pairs of TPPA ligands bridged face-to-face by coordination to [Ni2(μ2-OH)]3+ nodes (C and A). Pairs of cis-As atoms are related by a 2-fold inversion, so the lone pairs share a 2-D plane, intersecting at a 98.8° apex (Figure S5). A geometric investigation of chelated molecular diarsine complexes in the Cambridge Crystallographic Database reveals As–M–As bite angles between 69.9° and 95.1°, which are more acute than the putative 98.8° bite angle in ACM-1. Furthermore, hypothetical symmetric chelation of a metal center into an As2 pocket in ACM-1 would incur M–As distances of 3.18 Å (Figure S5); this is 31% longer than the average M–As bond found in the database (2.43 Å; 2.21–2.91 Å; Figure S6). Thus, the cis-As2 sites in ACM-1 appeared to be too distal to readily chelate low-valent metals.
elements.clean_text: Closer examination of the extended structure of ACM-1 along the c-axis reveals pairs of As atoms arranged in a cis-orientation (C and A; purple atoms). This arrangement is derived from pairs of TPPA ligands bridged face-to-face by coordination to [Ni2(μ2-OH)]3+ nodes (C and A). Pairs of cis-As atoms are related by a 2-fold inversion, so the lone pairs share a 2-D plane, intersecting at a 98.8° apex (Figure S5). A geometric investigation of chelated molecular diarsine complexes in the Cambridge Crystallographic Database reveals As-M-As bite angles between 69.9° and 95.1°, which are more acute than the putative 98.8° bite angle in ACM-1. Furthermore, hypothetical symmetric chelation of a metal center into an As2 pocket in ACM-1 would incur M-As distances of 3.18 Å (Figure S5); this is 31% longer than the average M-As bond found in the database (2.43 Å; 2.21-2.91 Å; Figure S6). Thus, the cis-As2 sites in ACM-1 appeared to be too distal to readily chelate low-valent metals.

elements.content: Accordingly, when freshly prepared ACM-1 crystallites were treated with organic solutions containing Group 10 precursors (e.g., K2PtCl4, Pd­(COD)­Cl2, Pd­(MeCN)2Cl2, Pt­(SEt2)2Cl2), no noticeable changes were seen in the PXRD patterns. Alternatively, we treated ACM-1 with different group 11 organometallic precursors, assuming that it might be possible to cocoordinate multiple metal centers into the same cis-As2 pocket, to generate species that may not be observed in solution. Direct treatment of ACM-1 with (Me2S)­AuCl (4 equiv per TPPA) and standing overnight caused the crystallites to turn from emerald green to a darker gray color and the bulk showed distinct changes to the PXRD pattern (B and S7B). Notably, the formation of As–AuCl coordination bonds in ACM-1 proceeded with retention of crystallinity, permitting full SCXRD structural resolution of the modified ACM-1 using a conventional X-ray source.
elements.clean_text: Accordingly, when freshly prepared ACM-1 crystallites were treated with organic solutions containing Group 10 precursors (e.g., K2PtCl4, Pd(COD)Cl2, Pd(MeCN)2Cl2, Pt(SEt2)2Cl2), no noticeable changes were seen in the PXRD patterns. Alternatively, we treated ACM-1 with different group 11 organometallic precursors, assuming that it might be possible to cocoordinate multiple metal centers into the same cis-As2 pocket, to generate species that may not be observed in solution. Direct treatment of ACM-1 with (Me2S)AuCl (4 equiv per TPPA) and standing overnight caused the crystallites to turn from emerald green to a darker gray color and the bulk showed distinct changes to the PXRD pattern (B and S7B). Notably, the formation of As-AuCl coordination bonds in ACM-1 proceeded with retention of crystallinity, permitting full SCXRD structural resolution of the modified ACM-1 using a conventional X-ray source.

elements.content: The new material (Au–ACM-1) inhabits the same space group as the parent MOF, with a noticeable distortion to the unit cell. The origin of this distortion is a twisting of the As2 pocket, which moves adjacent As lone pairs out-of-plane and facilitates cocoordination of two As–AuCl moieties per pocket (A). The refined AuCl site occupancy from the SCXRD solution was 78%, in excellent agreement with ICP-OES studies (average AuCl loading = 78.1%; Table S1). Au–ACM-1 samples were also analyzed by a combination of PXRD, scanning and transmission electron microscopy (S/TEM) coupled with 2-D energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to confirm that no larger Au(0) species were present (Figures S8–S11).
elements.clean_text: The new material (Au-ACM-1) inhabits the same space group as the parent MOF, with a noticeable distortion to the unit cell. The origin of this distortion is a twisting of the As2 pocket, which moves adjacent As lone pairs out-of-plane and facilitates cocoordination of two As-AuCl moieties per pocket (A). The refined AuCl site occupancy from the SCXRD solution was 78%, in excellent agreement with ICP-OES studies (average AuCl loading = 78.1%; Table S1). Au-ACM-1 samples were also analyzed by a combination of PXRD, scanning and transmission electron microscopy (S/TEM) coupled with 2-D energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to confirm that no larger Au(0) species were present (Figures S8-S11).

elements.content: (A) Comparison of single crystal structures of As2 pockets in ACM-1 before and after addition of AuCl (Au = gold; Cl = dark green). Inset: sawhorse projection of the aurophilically bound Au2 dimers, with associated bond distances (Å). (B) Extended space-filling view in the ac-plane showing location of AuCl moieties and retention of major pore openings.
elements.clean_text: 4  (A) Comparison of single crystal structures of As2 pockets in ACM-1 before and after addition of AuCl (Au = gold; Cl = dark green). Inset: sawhorse projection of the aurophilically bound Au2 dimers, with associated bond distances (Å). (B) Extended space-filling view in the ac-plane showing location of AuCl moieties and retention of major pore openings.

elements.content: Arguably, the most interesting aspect of this result is the geometric nature of the Au dimers generated in Au–ACM-1 (A; inset): there is a very short-range Au···Au contact distance of 2.76 Å in each dimer. Aurophilic bonding between Au­(I) centers is a well-known phenomenon due to closed-shell 5d 10 interactions, which can enhance the solid-state luminescence. Numerous aurophilically bonded complexes have been structurally characterized; the shortest Au···Au distances are generally correlated with the presence of more electron-donating ligands. Dimers with the general formula [LAuX]2 (L = PR3, RCN, R = S, etc. ; X = Cl–, Br–, I–) display Au···Au distances between 2.84 and 3.43 Å (avg. = 3.10 Å; Figure S12). It is therefore fascinating that an extraordinarily short Au···Au distance is obtained using ACM-1 as an SSL, and that the [AsAuCl]2 dimers also force a distortion of the MOF scaffold. Presumably, the rigidity of the MOF limits the extent of this distortion, resulting in significant compression of the Au···Au distance versus what is observed in geometrically relaxed (equilibrium) molecular complexes.
elements.clean_text: Arguably, the most interesting aspect of this result is the geometric nature of the Au dimers generated in Au-ACM-1 (A; inset): there is a very short-range Au⋅⋅⋅Au contact distance of 2.76 Å in each dimer. Aurophilic bonding between Au(I) centers is a well-known phenomenon due to closed-shell 5d 10 interactions, which can enhance the solid-state luminescence. Numerous aurophilically bonded complexes have been structurally characterized; the shortest Au⋅⋅⋅Au distances are generally correlated with the presence of more electron-donating ligands. Dimers with the general formula [LAuX]2 (L = PR3, RCN, R = S, etc. ; X = Cl-, Br-, I-) display Au⋅⋅⋅Au distances between 2.84 and 3.43 Å (avg. = 3.10 Å; Figure S12). It is therefore fascinating that an extraordinarily short Au⋅⋅⋅Au distance is obtained using ACM-1 as an SSL, and that the [AsAuCl]2 dimers also force a distortion of the MOF scaffold. Presumably, the rigidity of the MOF limits the extent of this distortion, resulting in significant compression of the Au⋅⋅⋅Au distance versus what is observed in geometrically relaxed (equilibrium) molecular complexes.

elements.content: The solid-state properties of Au–ACM-1 are also interesting. First, the BET surface areas of Au–ACM-1 measured using both N2 and CO2 probe gases (664 and 674 m2 g–1, respectively; A and S13) and the corresponding pore volumes (0.28 and 0.34 cm3 g–1, respectively) are between 40% and 50% lower than for the parent ACM-1; this is not unexpected due to the addition of AuCl groups inside the micropores. However, the H2 capacity of Au–ACM-1 approximately doubles (218 to 454 cm3 mmol–1; A). This is noteworthy since the Au-functionalized material is significantly heavier than ACM-1 and indicates that H2 loading inside the Au­(I)-decorated pores is more optimal. Studies to better understand this behavior are currently under way using inelastic neutron scattering spectroscopy (INS). Second, Au–ACM-1 shows enhanced solid-state luminescence; materials containing aurophilic bonds are often strongly emissive. Compared to the emission profiles of ACM-1 and the TPPA ligand, a distinct feature was observed at 489 nm for Au–ACM-1 (in degassed CH2Cl2 at 77 K; Figure S14). The peaks observed at 431 and 463 nm are due to intraligand transitions (n→π* and π →π*), while the feature at 489 nm is likely also a ligand-based transition that is not observed for the free ligand. The emission peaks for Au–ACM-1 were blue-shifted due to lowering in energy of the ligand molecular orbitals upon Au­(I) binding; the sharpness and intensity of the emission peaks of Au–ACM-1 were also increased, likely due to the heavy-atom effect. The excited state lifetimes for ACM-1 (τ = 0.33 μs) and Au–ACM-1 (τ = 0.49 μs) were longer than the lifetime of free TPPA (τ = 0.28 μs), likely due to reduced conformational freedom of ligands in the MOF.
elements.clean_text: The solid-state properties of Au-ACM-1 are also interesting. First, the BET surface areas of Au-ACM-1 measured using both N2 and CO2 probe gases (664 and 674 m2 g-1, respectively; A and S13) and the corresponding pore volumes (0.28 and 0.34 cm3 g-1, respectively) are between 40% and 50% lower than for the parent ACM-1; this is not unexpected due to the addition of AuCl groups inside the micropores. However, the H2 capacity of Au-ACM-1 approximately doubles (218 to 454 cm3 mmol-1; A). This is noteworthy since the Au-functionalized material is significantly heavier than ACM-1 and indicates that H2 loading inside the Au(I)-decorated pores is more optimal. Studies to better understand this behavior are currently under way using inelastic neutron scattering spectroscopy (INS). Second, Au-ACM-1 shows enhanced solid-state luminescence; materials containing aurophilic bonds are often strongly emissive. Compared to the emission profiles of ACM-1 and the TPPA ligand, a distinct feature was observed at 489 nm for Au-ACM-1 (in degassed CH2Cl2 at 77 K; Figure S14). The peaks observed at 431 and 463 nm are due to intraligand transitions (n→π* and π →π*), while the feature at 489 nm is likely also a ligand-based transition that is not observed for the free ligand. The emission peaks for Au-ACM-1 were blue-shifted due to lowering in energy of the ligand molecular orbitals upon Au(I) binding; the sharpness and intensity of the emission peaks of Au-ACM-1 were also increased, likely due to the heavy-atom effect. The excited state lifetimes for ACM-1 (τ = 0.33 μs) and Au-ACM-1 (τ = 0.49 μs) were longer than the lifetime of free TPPA (τ = 0.28 μs), likely due to reduced conformational freedom of ligands in the MOF.

elements.content: In summary, this initial work shows great promise for the use of organoarsine MOFs decorated with co-operative coordination pockets, as solid-state ligands for the generation of unusual, confined coordination complexes. We are presently investigating ways to tune the coordination pockets in ACM-1 to accommodate other low-valent metals of interest for small molecule activations.
elements.clean_text: In summary, this initial work shows great promise for the use of organoarsine MOFs decorated with co-operative coordination pockets, as solid-state ligands for the generation of unusual, confined coordination complexes. We are presently investigating ways to tune the coordination pockets in ACM-1 to accommodate other low-valent metals of interest for small molecule activations.

Full experimental procedures for TPPA, ACM-1 and Au–ACM-1; characterizing data for TPPA and the ACM-1 materials; NMR, FT-IR, TGA and XPS data; SEM/EDS and TEM images; additional BET and PXRD data (PDF)

cln_elements.content:
ACM-1 has a 3-D micropore structure with three types of pore windows ( and S4). The 3-fold symmetry of the TPPA ligands engenders triangular openings with a maximum accessible edge length of 13.4 Å lying parallel to the crystallographic a-axis (A). The largest, rhombus-shaped openings have accessible corner-to-corner dimensions of 14.4 × 15.7 Å (B). Smaller hexagonal pores of accessible diameter = 14. 3 Å lie parallel the c-axis (C). ACM-1 shows permanent porosity upon activation at 75 °C in vacuo. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) shows that loss of solvent from the pores occurs between 25 and 125 °C (∼31% of the total starting mass), after which there is no further mass loss until the onset of degradation ca. 325 °C (Figure S2). The calculated BET surface areas using CO2 and N2 are 1154 and 1021 m2 g–1, respectively. The CO2 pore volume of 0.60 cm3 g–1 is in close agreement with the value obtained using the VOID utility in Platon (0.63 cm3 g–1; corresponding to a 53% accessible void space). ACM-1 shows highly reversible Type-I sorption of a number of small molecule probe gases without hysteresis (A and S3). The measured adsorption capacities for various gases were: N2, 545 cm3 mmol–1 (77 K, 0.95 atm); CO2, 486 cm3 mmol–1 (196 K, 0.95 atm); O2, 575 cm3 mmol–1 (77 K, 0.20 atm); and H2, 218 cm3 mmol–1 (77 K, 0.95 atm).

The solid-state properties of Au–ACM-1 are also interesting. First, the BET surface areas of Au–ACM-1 measured using both N2 and CO2 probe gases (664 and 674 m2 g–1, respectively; A and S13) and the corresponding pore volumes (0.28 and 0.34 cm3 g–1, respectively) are between 40% and 50% lower than for the parent ACM-1; this is not unexpected due to the addition of AuCl groups inside the micropores. However, the H2 capacity of Au–ACM-1 approximately doubles (218 to 454 cm3 mmol–1; A). This is noteworthy since the Au-functionalized material is significantly heavier than ACM-1 and indicates that H2 loading inside the Au­(I)-decorated pores is more optimal. Studies to better understand this behavior are currently under way using inelastic neutron scattering spectroscopy (INS). Second, Au–ACM-1 shows enhanced solid-state luminescence; materials containing aurophilic bonds are often strongly emissive. Compared to the emission profiles of ACM-1 and the TPPA ligand, a distinct feature was observed at 489 nm for Au–ACM-1 (in degassed CH2Cl2 at 77 K; Figure S14). The peaks observed at 431 and 463 nm are due to intraligand transitions (n→π* and π →π*), while the feature at 489 nm is likely also a ligand-based transition that is not observed for the free ligand. The emission peaks for Au–ACM-1 were blue-shifted due to lowering in energy of the ligand molecular orbitals upon Au­(I) binding; the sharpness and intensity of the emission peaks of Au–ACM-1 were also increased, likely due to the heavy-atom effect. The excited state lifetimes for ACM-1 (τ = 0.33 μs) and Au–ACM-1 (τ = 0.49 μs) were longer than the lifetime of free TPPA (τ = 0.28 μs), likely due to reduced conformational freedom of ligands in the MOF.
cln_elements.clean_text:
ACM-1 has a 3-D micropore structure with three types of pore windows ( and S4). The 3-fold symmetry of the TPPA ligands engenders triangular openings with a maximum accessible edge length of 13.4 Å lying parallel to the crystallographic a-axis (A). The largest, rhombus-shaped openings have accessible corner-to-corner dimensions of 14.4 × 15.7 Å (B). Smaller hexagonal pores of accessible diameter = 14. 3 Å lie parallel the c-axis (C). ACM-1 shows permanent porosity upon activation at 75 °C in vacuo. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) shows that loss of solvent from the pores occurs between 25 and 125 °C (~31% of the total starting mass), after which there is no further mass loss until the onset of degradation ca. 325 °C (Figure S2). The calculated BET surface areas using CO2 and N2 are 1154 and 1021 m2 g-1, respectively. The CO2 pore volume of 0.60 cm3 g-1 is in close agreement with the value obtained using the VOID utility in Platon (0.63 cm3 g-1; corresponding to a 53% accessible void space). ACM-1 shows highly reversible Type-I sorption of a number of small molecule probe gases without hysteresis (A and S3). The measured adsorption capacities for various gases were: N2, 545 cm3 mmol-1 (77 K, 0.95 atm); CO2, 486 cm3 mmol-1 (196 K, 0.95 atm); O2, 575 cm3 mmol-1 (77 K, 0.20 atm); and H2, 218 cm3 mmol-1 (77 K, 0.95 atm).

The solid-state properties of Au-ACM-1 are also interesting. First, the BET surface areas of Au-ACM-1 measured using both N2 and CO2 probe gases (664 and 674 m2 g-1, respectively; A and S13) and the corresponding pore volumes (0.28 and 0.34 cm3 g-1, respectively) are between 40% and 50% lower than for the parent ACM-1; this is not unexpected due to the addition of AuCl groups inside the micropores. However, the H2 capacity of Au-ACM-1 approximately doubles (218 to 454 cm3 mmol-1; A). This is noteworthy since the Au-functionalized material is significantly heavier than ACM-1 and indicates that H2 loading inside the Au(I)-decorated pores is more optimal. Studies to better understand this behavior are currently under way using inelastic neutron scattering spectroscopy (INS). Second, Au-ACM-1 shows enhanced solid-state luminescence; materials containing aurophilic bonds are often strongly emissive. Compared to the emission profiles of ACM-1 and the TPPA ligand, a distinct feature was observed at 489 nm for Au-ACM-1 (in degassed CH2Cl2 at 77 K; Figure S14). The peaks observed at 431 and 463 nm are due to intraligand transitions (n→π* and π →π*), while the feature at 489 nm is likely also a ligand-based transition that is not observed for the free ligand. The emission peaks for Au-ACM-1 were blue-shifted due to lowering in energy of the ligand molecular orbitals upon Au(I) binding; the sharpness and intensity of the emission peaks of Au-ACM-1 were also increased, likely due to the heavy-atom effect. The excited state lifetimes for ACM-1 (τ = 0.33 μs) and Au-ACM-1 (τ = 0.49 μs) were longer than the lifetime of free TPPA (τ = 0.28 μs), likely due to reduced conformational freedom of ligands in the MOF.

decomposition temperature.type: loss of solvent from the pores

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis Scheme for ACM-1<xref ref-type="fn" rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

(i) AsCl3, THF, −78 °C → +25 °C; (ii) Pd­(PPh3)4 (5 mol %), 4:1:1 toluene:ethanol:H2O, 105 °C, 96 h; (iii) Ni­(BF4)2, 5:2:1 DMF:methanol:H2O, 75 °C, 48–96 h.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis Scheme for ACM-1      a (i) AsCl3, THF, -78 °C → +25 °C; (ii) Pd(PPh3)4 (5 mol %), 4:1:1 toluene:ethanol:H2O, 105 °C, 96 h; (iii) Ni(BF4)2, 5:2:1 DMF:methanol:H2O, 75 °C, 48-96 h.

cln_elements.content: (A) Extended asymmetric unit of ACM-1 showing the basic network connectivity; BPD ligands are drawn in cyan. (B) Alternative view of an 8-connected [Ni2(μ2-OH)]3+ node. (C) Distorted pyramidal environment of the As­(III) donor site, and bond angles (deg).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (A) Extended asymmetric unit of ACM-1 showing the basic network connectivity; BPD ligands are drawn in cyan. (B) Alternative view of an 8-connected [Ni2(μ2-OH)]3+ node. (C) Distorted pyramidal environment of the As(III) donor site, and bond angles (deg).

cln_elements.content: Space-filling representations of the extended structure of ACM-1 viewed in (A) the crystallographic bc-plane; (B) in the ac-plane; (C) the ab-plane, showing the cis-As2 pockets (purple atoms).
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Space-filling representations of the extended structure of ACM-1 viewed in (A) the crystallographic bc-plane; (B) in the ac-plane; (C) the ab-plane, showing the cis-As2 pockets (purple atoms).

cln_elements.content: (A) Comparison of adsorption isotherms for ACM-1 (solid markers) versus Au–ACM-1 (open markers): red = O2, 77 K; blue = N2, 77 K; green = CO2, 196 K; black = H2, 77 K. (B) Comparison of the simulated and observed PXRD patterns for ACM-1 (black = model; blue = observed) and Au–ACM-1 (red = model; green = observed).
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  (A) Comparison of adsorption isotherms for ACM-1 (solid markers) versus Au-ACM-1 (open markers): red = O2, 77 K; blue = N2, 77 K; green = CO2, 196 K; black = H2, 77 K. (B) Comparison of the simulated and observed PXRD patterns for ACM-1 (black = model; blue = observed) and Au-ACM-1 (red = model; green = observed).

cln_elements.content: (A) Comparison of single crystal structures of As2 pockets in ACM-1 before and after addition of AuCl (Au = gold; Cl = dark green). Inset: sawhorse projection of the aurophilically bound Au2 dimers, with associated bond distances (Å). (B) Extended space-filling view in the ac-plane showing location of AuCl moieties and retention of major pore openings.
cln_elements.clean_text: 4  (A) Comparison of single crystal structures of As2 pockets in ACM-1 before and after addition of AuCl (Au = gold; Cl = dark green). Inset: sawhorse projection of the aurophilically bound Au2 dimers, with associated bond distances (Å). (B) Extended space-filling view in the ac-plane showing location of AuCl moieties and retention of major pore openings.

metadata.title:
Organoarsine
Metal–Organic Framework with cis-Diarsine
Pockets for the Installation of Uniquely Confined
Metal Complexes
